B000005HLV|5.0|\\"Black Metal\\" is the term used to describe this music.  With the possible exception of Darkthrone and early Burzum, I would have to say that \\"black\\" has never been better used as an adjective.  The atmosphere contained on this CD completely transcends cheesy synths or excessive corpse paint.  You will feel the harshness of a Norweigian snow storm on this disc.  Cold, grim, evil music made by truly evil people (read \\"Lords of Chaos\\" if you don't believe me). Beginning with the inhumanly fast power-chord opening of \\"Funeral Fog,\\" through the death metal plodding of \\"Freezing Moon,\\" to the haunting title track,  the listener is kept within a blizzard of chainsaw guitars, vomited vocals, and blastbeats to rival a mechanized tank assault.  Attila's utterly bizzare vocals are either eerie, dissonat howls from hell or an ungody amalgamation of opera and death-metal grunts.  Hellhammer puts on a truly amazing display of high-speed beats here, one often wonders if any human could truly drums at such a vicious tempos.  The murdered Euronymous shows why he is what every black metal guitarist wishes they were.  And, contrary to popular belief, Varg \\"Count Grishnack\\" Vikernes' bass parts were *not* taken from this album, and this fact alone is quite frightening<br />When black metal is mentioned, the violent deeds of the scene's progenitors often overshadow the music.  But rest assured,  Mayhem's \\"De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas\\" delivers the icy goods with little to be desired.  If you want to see what black metal is, buy this album.  And, while you're at it, get Darkthrone's \\"A Blaze in the Northern Sky\\" and \\"Under a Funeral Moon.\\"  With these CD's you will experience some of the most evil and unforgiving metal to ever be pressed.  Black metal, indeed.

B000069AUI|5.0|I admit I was a little late to the Coldplay bandwagon, but I have become completely mesmerized by the music and the lyrics of this CD.  I happened to see their performance on the Grammys of their song &quot;Politik&quot; and it was one of those whoa! moments that encouarged me to check out their album.  For some reason, I have not quite been able to actually pinpoint a 'sounds like' which connects Coldplay to any other one singer or one band.  Yeah, Chris Martin has a certain (mellow) Dave Matthews sound on some of his songs and some of the arrangements do tend to remind you of the more melancholy Pink Floyd. B000069HKH|5.0|First of all, let me say that many of Springsteen's fans have made fools of themselves in their reaction to Bruce's loss to Norah Jones at the Grammies.  If you read any online forums or Backstreets magazine, you'll see plenty of sore losers who unfairly bash Norah because she had the combination of luck and talent to win album and song of the year over Bruce.  Some of them are pretty mean-spirited and hateful, and I'm embarrased to say that I share an interest with some of these people.  Norah Jones is a young, fresh artist who deserves to be heard as much as Bruce did (but wasn't) with his first several albums.  That being said, The Rising should have won Album of the Year.  That doesn't diminish Norah Jones, but I think the fact that she doesn't write her own material while Bruce does puts him ahead of the game in competition for the best album.  Bruce's loss also doesn't diminish that this is an album worthy of every possible honor.  Time will tell how Norah will fare (and I think she'll be around a long time), but Bruce is an established classic artist and this is one of his finest moments.<br />The Rising finds Bruce Springsteen reunited with The E Street Band (it's confusing the way this is hyped, but he techincally hadn't recorded a full album with the band since Born in the USA, even though various members of the band have appeared on various recordings since then and I think its a little deceptive to present it this way).  They sound like themselves, but then again they don't.  This, I think is thanks to Brendan O'Brien, the producer that Bruce chose to work with for The Rising.  There's a new depth and texture to Bruce's sound- lots of strings and other exotic instruments that don't often find there way onto a Springsteen album.  I think O'Brien can be thanked for a lot of this, as well as for the fact that it actually didn't take years for Bruce to finish the album.  Let's hope that this leads to a long and productive relationship.<br />There's hardly athrowaway song on the album.  Standouts for me include the title song, Lonesome Day, Into the Fire, Nothing Man (an underrated gem of an album track), Further On Up the Road and Waitin' on a Sunny Day.  The only song that I think sounds rather generic is Countin' On a Miracle- it seems to fit in with the bland stuff that Bruce recorded in the early 90s (heard on Disc 4 of his Tracks box-set) and doesn't come to life any better when performed in concert.  Bruce's voice is in top form, and he's lost the appropriate but dry twang he adapted for The Ghost of Tom Joad and which painfully leaked its way into some of his live performances since then.  <br />It's pretty well known that this CD is seen as a 9/11 concept album (making it all the more surprising that it didn't win the Grammy), and Bruce himself hyped the heck out of that angle.  But I don't really see it as that.  Sure, there are obvious references to rescuers sacrificing themselves and to empty skylines, but I see this CD as being more about loss in general, and how we cope when we're left behind.  I don't know that this angle was really brought up (and well it shouldn't have been), but I believe that Bruce lost his father within the past four or five years.  That undoubtedly influenced this CD as much as did the events of 9-11.  LOSS is the concept that ties most of the songs here. While we were all impacted by the terrorist attacks- whether through loss of a loved one or employment or sense of security- the losses conveyed here are on a much more personal level than simply being specific to 9-11.  Anyone who has ever experienced the absence of a loved one (whether through death or the breakup of a relationship) can identify with the sentiments of \\"You're Missing\\" or \\"Empty Sky\\".  \\"The Fuse\\" is about two lovers, possibly strangers, drawn into intimacy through some event- maybe a funeral, maybe 9-11.  \\"Nothing Man\\" is about surviving- or maybe being in some way responsible for- some violent event, and the accompanying guilt and numbness.  Life goes on for the main character, but its not the same and maybe not worthwhile anymore (is the pearl and silver lying on his table a gun?)  There are also some mildly political songs- \\"Paradise\\", about both a suicide bomber and the loved one of a victim presumably killed by the terrorist.  \\"Worlds Apart\\" tells of two lovers from vastly different cultures- possibly an American and an Afghani and the gulf caused by these differences.  So if you're looking for a gung-ho 9-11 album that talks about national anger and reactionary patriotism, with references to airplanes and hijackers and heroic passengers, you're not going to find it.  The 9-11 angle is at best subtle and most of the time quite general.  And frankly, I think that's a good thing.<br />It's a shame that Bruce Springsteen gets so little airplay, and that he had to rely on his (overdone) media appearances to promote this fine CD.  Let's hope that this is the start of a long period of prodcutivity for Bruce and that he continues to record and to tour well into the next two or three decades.  This CD will tide us over nicely until then...
B00000J7JO|2.0|I've never been much of a Chili Peppers fan but I bought this CD because I liked Scar Tissue and the title track (even thought I think people will agree with me that &quot;californication&quot; was far overplayed on the radio). 0446310786|5.0|'To Kill a mocking bird' is a tapestry of anectodes vividly brought out by an excellent american raconteur - Harper Lee. It's a narration of the childhood days of a girl nicknamed Scout, who is too intelligent for her age with the intransigence of a child, in which her apparently dull & talentless father, Atticus Finch, reveals his heroism through his headstrong uprightness & optimism to rebel against the amoral racist prejudices of his village.   The beauty of this book is its style, which is effective in convincing the reader that the whole story is from the viewpoint of an immature young girl. Lee achieves this by intertwining the main plot, as if it were unimportant (from the girl's viewpoint), with the story of a mysterious neighbour Boo Radley, whom the trio of Scout, Jem - Scout's tutelary elder brother and Dill - their friend, set out to discover. The quiet wit that is strewn all over is another plus that makes it an unstoppable read.

0783229526|5.0|This cult classic is just that for several reasons.  Under the brilliant directing talent of former Pythoner Terry Gilliam one of the great counter culture books of all time unfolds with mass hysteria.  Johnny Depp steps into the twisted head of the great Hunter S. Thompson and takes us with him, consuming enough drugs to kill a horse.  Benecio Del Toro adds to this colorful cocktail by pushing Depp's character to the deepest depths of what can only be called Gonzo journalism.  This psycadelic, colorful romp through Las Vegas is hilarious, rediculous, and at times thought provoking, and is best served with everything in your medicine cabinet and a few beers.  After all, anything worth doing, is worth doing right.

B000002HH2|5.0|Until recently, I could not have named a specific Bjork song. Certainly, I had heard of Bjork, but somehow I had managed to miss her music. One night I was sitting in my room, casually watching a cable music channel here in Australia and the film clip for 'It's oh so quiet' came on. I was very intrigue with not only the inventive film clip, but with the music as well. So to become aquainted with Bjork and her music, what better way than to start than with the CD from which that song was released. Though Post is several years old now (first released in 1995), it sounds as fresh and modern as any CD released today.<br />Now to the difficult part of reviewing the music contained on Post. The music here is so diverse that there is no one label that could be attached to it. If I could use one word to describe Post it would have to be 'contrast'. I can't recall listening to a CD that was so diverse musically.<br />The first track, 'Army of me', is a heavily layered, rhythmic, booming song that certainly conjures up the impression of troops marching into war (appropriate in our present world climate). Bjork pours a lot of restrained anger into her performance here, both vocally and musically. It is from the second track where we see the theme of contrast come into play - 'Hyperballad' is a quiet track musically but the vocals have an 'on the edge of anger' feel. The contrast theme is further explored in the following track 'The modern things' where the song starts off sparsely with electronic synths and builds up layers including the addition of traditional instruments.<br />On Post, there are four main areas of contrast that are explored musically: contrasting different musically genres between tracks (the traditional jazzy feel of 'It's Oh so quiet' compared to the rest of the tracks), contrasting the volume in individual tracks (between instruments and between instruments and vocals), the use of electronic interments with traditional classical interments within the samesong and the use of traditional instruments to give a 'world music' feel to many tracks.<br />The track 'I miss you' illustrates these contrasts nicely -  we have the electronic instruments providing a mechanic, industrial sound and African type drums providing a world music feel.  The whole track comprises contrasts between the industrial and the traditional, all with subtle volume changes throughout. <br />Post has certainly provided me with a wonderful introduction to the world of Bjork. These tracks are not just cleverly crafted pop songs designed to sell bucket loads. These are well crafted, original and thought-provoking pieces of music designed not only to be enjoyed, but to also stimulate the thoughts and emotions. I will certainly be exploring further Bjork works in the future.

B000002KCC|5.0|Neil Young's \\"Tonight's the Night\\" is a timeless masterpiece. The album was recorded somewhat haphazardly and apparently in various stages of inebriation, but this all adds to the tragic thematic continuity and tone of the album. What makes this album so refreshing is that its production is not highly polished like Young's more recent efforts. What you get here is a collection of well-written, painfully honest songs that are devoid of the cliches that occasionally mar Young's work. There isn't a bad song on the entire album. These are songs of experience that will resonate deeply if you are looking for an album that provides a penetrating insight into humanity's struggle with tragedy and loss. And, by the way, the album also consistently provides some of the excellent rock music we all love and adore in Neil's collaborations with Crazy Horse. This album will likely be a permanent fixture in your collection.

B00005JLSC|4.0|CHICAGO tells the tale of Roxie Hart (Renee Zellweger) who wants to become a star in the jazz clubs of Chicago.  Unfortunately, she hits a snag on her path to stardom when she murders the man with whom she had been having an affair.  As she is arrested, her idol, jazz chanteuse Velma Kelly (Catherine Zeta-Jones) is also taken off to jail for murdering her unfaithful husband.  Roxie watches as the press flock to Velma, thanks to the talents of hot-shot lawyer Billy Flynn (Richard Gere), and when she eventually gets Flynn to take on her case as well she suddenly finds herself a headliner -- in the newspapers, anyway.<br />Zeta-Jones has the opening number which sets the stage for the musical, and she does a terrific job.  In fact, most of the vocal and dance performances of the cast are excellent.  Gere turns in a solid performance as Billy Flynn, and supporting players Queen Latifah and John C. Reilly steal the spotlight with exceptionally strong numbers.  The biggest disappointment in my mind was in Zellweger's performance -- Roxie is the star of the show and I didn't feel that she truly filled the role. I frequently found her presence distracting.<br />Director Rob Marshall, known previously for directing the television adaptions of the musicals ANNIE and CINDERELLA, helps the audience accept the fact that the characters spontaneously break into song and dance -- a problem in many musicals on screen and on stage -- by making these sequences spring from Roxie's imagination.  The staging of \\"We Both Reached For the Gun\\" is fantastic.<br />I can't speak to how closely Marshall's CHICAGO resembles the current Broadway show or the original Broadway cast.  But in its own light, CHICAGO is a very entertaining film that proves that the musical genre is far from dead.

B000002KHB|5.0|One critic has written that this is one of three in the 'Holy Trinity' of metal albums, with Sabbath's Paranoid and Zeppelin's ZOSO. B000003S0D|5.0|King Crimson has gone through many changes since its inception, but it was always a case of brilliant musicians replacing brilliant musicians, and there's really no room to give you any band history here; I'd rather discuss this most phenomenal album.  What's special about LIZARD (1970) is the contribution from the jazz players.  Mark Charig (cornet) and Nick Evans (trombone, can be heard on Soft Machine THIRD) were joined by the dazzling Keith Tippet (returning on piano).  These three musicians were instrumental in generating much of this music's added enchantment.  And, here again, we get Pete Sinfield's captivating lyrics, which are a world unto themselves and some of the most entertaining lyrics in all of rock.<br />The magic begins at once with the hushed introduction to &quot;Cirkus.&quot;  The theme is peaceful and the embellishment almost twinkles.  Then the band kicks in with a loud, eerie, minor-infused, twisted-smile-like riff and the song proceeds, the guitar and drums refreshingly hitting all the accents you wouldn't expect them to.  And at the end, Mark Charig's trumpet solo takes us to the stratosphere.  &quot;Indoor Games&quot; is a complete change of mood.  Andy McCulloch's drumming is superb in this intensely bluesy piece.  The bridge gets cosmic, and then there's a pleasingly playful improvisation between sax and guitar.  The end is a gas, as Gordon Haskell's laughter (and such) abruptly segues to the highly sardonic opening riff (more twisted-smile stuff) of &quot;Happy Family.&quot;  Here, we are delighted by Tippet's deliciously &quot;out&quot; piano playing, Haskell's very altered vocals and another stellar group-jam with flute and trombone.  (It's pretty easy to guess that this song is about The Beatles.)  &quot;Lady Of The Dancing Water&quot; is a gorgeous tune, beautifully sung and beautifully ornamented with guitar, flute and trombone.  Piano and percussion also make a subtle appearance in this calming, wonderfully lazy tune.<br />The haunting voice of Jon Anderson (Yes) mystifies us in the opening section of the title cut.  Keith Tippet blows us away with his brilliant countermelodies.  When &quot;Bolero--The Peacock's Tale&quot; begins, mellotron enters and we are given a grand, wordless treatment of the verse theme--absolutely breathtaking in its beauty!  Toward the end of the oboe solo, Tippet's piano hints of the bluesy improvisation to come.  The horns then create the most spellbinding and meaningful improvisation on a theme I've ever heard on a rock album--enthralling in its detail, brilliant in its invention.  The music resolves, the ad-libbing goes away and the oboe returns to the gorgeous theme from before.  The Bolero section ends, and we get quite a foreboding atmosphere as we enter &quot;Battle Of The Glass Tears.&quot;  The battle begins--the drums wickedly bizarre, a menacing sax riff enters and the band eventually improvises around this eeriness.  After this fit of group interplay comes &quot;Prince Rupert's Lament,&quot; a gut-wrenching guitar solo by Fripp that cries in anguish.  And finally, the playful absurdity of &quot;Big Top&quot; (remember &quot;Cirkus&quot;?) eases the anguish from that pain-filled guitar solo.<br />I don't know if this is my favorite rock album, but it's close.  I usually point to LIZARD as one of the most brilliant rock albums because rock, jazz, intense imagination and incredible musicianship intelligently collide to produce one thoroughly engaging work of art.  It is a monument of the genre.  I can't recommend this strongly enough to those who enjoy their music on the progressive side.  It differs in sound from all other King Crimson albums, but it is the most developed, the most advanced of any they made.  Because there is so much thematic detail involved here, LIZARD will grow on you the more you listen to it.  The music is deep, and richly rewarding.<br />LIZARD also has the coolest album cover ever.  But you really need the vinyl LP jacket to see allthe detail.  Don't pass this by.<br />Cheers,<br />Murraythe detail.  Don't pass this by.<br />Cheers,<br />Murray

B00000DOYH|5.0|Led Zeppelin doubles up on the fun in this 1975 double album, which makes sense since it had been two years since the release of \\"Houses of the Holy.\\"  Repeated listening makes it clear that each disc should be taken on its own terms.  Every time I listen to Disc One of \\"Physical Graffiti\\" I come to the conclusion that most of these songs were created out of jam sessions, as opposed to Page and Plant sitting down in the living room and working on tunes. You get the feeling Jimmy Page was fooling around, found some guitar riff that he liked and then Led Zeppelin fashioned an entire song out of it (e.g., \\"Custard Pie\\" and \\"Houses of the Holy\\"). The same thing with John Paul Jones's organ work on \\"Trampled Under Foot\\" and John Bonham's drumming on \\"Kashmir.\\" Clearly \\"Physical Graffiti\\" is Led Zeppelin's most collaborative album, with Jones and Bonham getting credits on six of the 15 tracks. While \\"Kashmir\\" has always been the most recognizable song on the album, long before Puff Daddy remixed it for the giant green lizard movie bomb, the group's true showpiece is the 11:08 \\"In My Time of Dying,\\" which finally gets the boys back in the neighborhood of the blues (along with \\"Boogie With Stu\\" and a few other tracks). \\"Dying\\" is the longest studio track in the entire Led Zep repertoire and one of four songs 6:55 or longer on the album. Who needs A.M. Top 40 air play?<br />In contrast Disc Two contain the lighter songs, the acoustic \\"Bron-Yr-Aur\\" and the cutesy \\"Down By The Seaside,\\" as well as another attempt to duplicate \\"Stairway to Heaven\\" with \\"Ten Years Gone,\\" before getting back to big time rock and roll (e.g., \\"The Wanton Song\\" and \\"Sick Again\\").  This is clearly the more experimental disc in the set, although I would not go so far as to suggest that the second comprises the \\"graffti\\" to the \\"physical\\" first.  More than any other Led Zeppelin album, \\"Physical Graffiti\\" reminds us that while Page and Plant were always out in front the rhythm section of Jones and Bonham was equally as good, even if the pair were under appreciated in comparison. Along with their first and fourth albums, this is one of Led Zeppelin's best, its filler cuts more than compensated for by the overall ambition of the effort.nham was equally as good, even if the pair were under appreciated in comparison. Along with their first and fourth albums, this is one of Led Zeppelin's best, its filler cuts more than compensated for by the overall ambition of the effort.

B00005MAM2|5.0|At least until \\"Spirited Away\\" becomes available on DVD this week there is essentialy a tossup between \\"Akira\\" and \\"Princess Mononoke\\" as to which film should serve as the introduction of a neophyte to the wonderful world of anime.  Either film would serve just fine and while I watched \\"Mononoke-hime\\" first, I would recommend \\"Akira\\" as the first choice.  However, whichever way you go if this is your first anime film you need to be aware that all of these films set standards that will put most other films in the genre to shame.<br />Katsuhiro tomo's 1988 masterpiece is a cyperbunk epic about a group of teenage bikers in neo-Tokyo who get caught up in top secret experiments by the government.  But what could be simply a collison between \\"The Wild One\\" and \\"Blade Runner\\" becomes much more in tomo's hands.  The notion that the film is \\"visually excessive\\" is a gross understatement; for those who have tolerated the minimalist animation and recurring film loops of animation on both sides of the Pacific Ocean, \\"Akira\\" is as far removed from cheap Saturday morning cartoons as you can get.  As far as tomo is concerned even when it comes to the faces in the background crowd, attention must be paid.<br />The story is a distillation of years of tomo's manga and why those who have actually read all of \\"Akira\\" books can bemoan that which has been ommitted in the same manner those who loved Frank Herbert's \\"Dune\\" lamented the David Lynch film, I think those of us who are completely ignorant of tomo's epic can understand and enjoy the film version (due in large measure to a new and improved dub on the DVD).  Obviously there is more depth to the story of \\"Akira,\\" and many will no doubt be inspired to check out the American reprints of the manga to enjoy the story in its entirety, but tomo has clearly taken pains to craft this \\"short\\" (124 minute) version for general consumption.<br />A confrontation between rival biker gangs leads to an encounter with an odd looking child before all of them are whisked away by the military.  We then learn about the legendary Akira, a psychic who destroyed Tokyo a generation earlier with a powerful mind blast.  The government is try to understand and harness the power of these psychics and when they take Tetsuo, one of the bikers, to experiment on at their secret base it is up to Kaneda to rescue his friend (and impress the girl, Kel).  Then Tetsuo not only gains godlike powers but goes insane and the future of everyone and everything is called into question.<br />Ultimately, \\"Akira\\" triumphs because the story is as complex as the animation is detailed (160,000 cells).  The characters might be the stereotypical conventions of the genre but tomo brings nuances to all of them, sometimes through nothing more than the look on their face.  \\"Grave of the Fireflies\\" is my favorite anime, but \\"Akira\\" is the most impressive I have seen to date.\\"  Even without Disc 2 in this Special Edition \\"Akira\\" rates five stars, but the extra material is extremely impressive, bearing witness to tomo's obsession with cramming detail into every single frame (e.g., Hauryki-Ya, the biker's seedy bar hangout).  \\"Akira Sound Clip\\" looks at the Taiko drum influenced soundtrack by Geinoh Yamashiro Gumi and there are other features, some of which were made for Japanese comic conventions, and most of which are treats for fans of tomo and his film.ing child before all of them are whisked away by the military.  We then learn about the legendary Akira, a psychic who destroyed Tokyo a generation earlier with a powerful mind blast.  The government is try to understand and harness the power of these psychics and when they take Tetsuo, one of the bikers, to experiment on at their secret base it is up to Kaneda to rescue his friend (and impress the girl, Kel).  Then Tetsuo not only gains godlike powers but goes insane and the future of everyone and everything is called into question.  <br />Ultimately, \\"Akira\\" triumphs because the story is as complex as the animation is detailed (160,000 cells). At home, he raises his son, Jem (Philip Alford), and his daughter, Scout (Mary Badham, Oscar-nominated), and teaches them about compassion and the evils of prejudice. \\"To Kill a Mockingbird\\" is the second best movie of 1962, next to \\"Lawrence of Arabia\\", and one of the best and most important movies of the 1960s. B00006M183|4.0|There have been mixed reviews about 2002's Riot Act.  Some people will cite it as Pearl Jam's best album to date, whereas others will say it continues the downward spiral started with Yield.  I (along with a fair number more) am sort of in between.  I have a hard time picking a favorite PJ record.  I like Yield, Vs., No Code... I like them all.  Notwithstanding, Riot Act may not be their best collection; but it's certainly not bad.  All the songs are intriguing one way or another.  Many of the songs are nothing new, but some are.  Here's a brief overview of the 15 tracks:<br />1. Can't Keep - 3.5/5 - The opener features some melodic music and some simplistic words.  It gives the impression of hard rock, but seems delicate at the same time.  It's reminiscent of something from Binaural (that`s rare here).<br />2. Save You - 5/5 - This is as \\"rockin\\" as it gets for Riot Act.  There's a large number of swears (primarily `fxck') and great negativity towards self.  This is undoubtedly one of the album's best; as it reminds me of a cross between \\"Hail, Hail\\" and \\"Brain Of J.\\".<br />3. Love Boat Captain - 4/5 - It's really an amazing track.  It's a good change from track two; both lyrically and musically.  The line `all you need is love' is quite different from `and fxck me if I say something you don't wanna hear' (in \\"Save You\\").  It starts slow, but picks up as it moves on.<br />4. Cropduster - 2.5/5 - Again, No Code comes to mind when hearing this song.  There's really nothing special within the music, but the words are surprising and (to some extent) enjoyable.<br />5. Ghost - 5/5 - This one has a very jittery start; which is good.  It's actually a favorite of mine since the chorus is very catchy.  I was a little startled by the short guitar solos, but you'll learn to love them over time.  Take note of the line `seeking new ways / before I miss it all'.<br />6. I Am Mine - 4.5/5 - I can easily see why this was the first single.  It's a great song, and leaves you wanting more.  Hence... you'll buy the CD.  And once you do that, you will soon realize there are other tracks that are better.  Eddie really gets personal here; don`t overlook it.<br />7. Thumbing My Way - 4.5/5 - Nothing too spectacular, but one of the few original songs.  And again, the music picks up as the song goes along.  This one just might be a hidden gem on Riot Act (even though some people say it`s the best).<br />8. You Are - 5/5 - This single-bound track holds (maybe) the best PJ verse ever: `love is a tower / of strength to me / I am the shoreline / but you're the sea'.  It's very refreshing; and features some uncharacteristic pauses, heavy background music, and even some `ooh wah' chants.  No doubt, it's one of the best.<br />9. (Wanted To) Get Right - 5/5 - Once more, No Code will come to mind when you hear this track.  It's fast, quick; and gives us the \\"rockin\\" PJ sound we are all used to.  Also, don't ignore the brilliant lyrics as you enjoy the music.  Unbelievable outgoing solo!<br />10. Green Disease - 3.5/5 - Here's a weird starter with mainly a lot of rhyming.  I have a hard time getting into this track; even though it's very likable.  If you don't appreciate the sound, you'll at least appreciate the lyrics.<br />11. Help Help - 2.5/5 - The opening stanza, `tell me what I wanna hear / this shxt's too good to be true' is as ironical as it gets for Pearl Jam.  But after the first two lines the song begins to fade.  It could've used a more \\"heavy\\" feel.<br />12. Bushleaguer - 2/5 - Its spoken word start is very, very weak.  That kind of makes it hard to enjoy--and in the end--the worst song on the album.  Had they left out the talking it might've developed into a better track.<br />13. Half Full - 3/5 - Believe it or not, this one has a country-bar feel to it.  Needless to say it is unlike anything else on the CD.  Again it's nothing special, but the fact it's so different makes it somewhat pleasurable.<br />14. Arc - ?/5 - Here Eddie sways in and outof Indian-like melodies for approximately one minute.  It's kind of puzzling and almost to the point of meaningless; but it's so short it won't even phase you.<br />15. All Or None - 5/5 - This is up there, with \\"All Those Yesterdays\\", as one of the best closers Pearl Jam has ever done.  The countless solos really take command of the song, and each line acts as a masterpiece in itself.  It's definitely one of the best.<br />For some people it may be weird to see Eddie Vedder without his grunge-ish haircut and vaporous look.  It seems the band have waived bye-bye to the years of grunge music and the comparisons to Alice In Chains and Soundgarden.  Their sound has certainly changed from Ten, but their prominence has not.  If you are an all-around Pearl Jam \\"fan\\", you will love this album.  Riot Act mixes the sound of most of the band's work (No Code, Yield, Binaural, Vs., and even some Vitalogy); and does a pretty good job when it's said and done.  I will say this is not PJ's best album.  But songs like \\"Get Right\\" and \\"Save You\\" are clearly among their best... ever.  Riot Act deserves a very strong 4 stars.  It's different, it's the same, it's noteworthy; but most importantly it's good music.  Enjoy this album for what it is; and ignore its random poor reviews.of Indian-like melodies for approximately one minute.  It's kind of puzzling and almost to the point of meaningless; but it's so short it won't even phase you.<br />15. All Or None - 5/5 - This is up there, with \\"All Those Yesterdays\\", as one of the best closers Pearl Jam has ever done.  The countless solos really take command of the song, and each line acts as a masterpiece in itself.  It's definitely one of the best.<br />For some people it may be weird to see Eddie Vedder without his grunge-ish haircut and vaporous look.  It seems the band have waived bye-bye to the years of grunge music and the comparisons to Alice In Chains and Soundgarden.  Their sound has certainly changed from Ten, but their prominence has not.  If you are an all-around Pearl Jam \\"fan\\", you will love this album.  Riot Act mixes the sound of most of the band's work (No Code, Yield, Binaural, Vs., and even some Vitalogy); and does a pretty good job when it's said and done.  I will say this is not PJ's best album.  But songs like \\"Get Right\\" and \\"Save You\\" are clearly among their best... ever.  Riot Act deserves a very strong 4 stars.  It's different, it's the same, it's noteworthy; but most importantly it's good music.  Enjoy this album for what it is; and ignore its random poor reviews.

0375414053|4.0|The easy answer to the title question \\"I Don't Know How She Does It\\" is: Just throw money at it.  Heroine Kate Reddy, has cash in abundance. Right then, I knew I'd like the book.  I wasn't in for an exhausting drama of baby on hip, phone in ear, mop in hand, and brain numb with juggling finances. Good!<br />Kate is a very well compensated corporate hedge fund manager in The City (in the U.S., translate to Wall Street). Her job is 24/7, stress-filled, and calls for international travel.  She lives in an almost renovated townhouse with her darling almost-perfect husband and two children, baby Ben and kindergartner Emily.  Kate grew up poor with an irresponsible father. Husband Richard's background is achingly comfortable and stable.  That's the setup.  Kate, though awesomely energetic, witty, capable and yes--lovable-- can manage only if Everything Goes Perfectly.  One slip, and the entire structure collapses. She is sleep deprived, nervous, self-punishing and a shocking nag.  The burning question: Can she somehow do a perfect job and be a Perfect Mother and Wife? No, of course, not but contrary to what many reviewers complained about, Kate did not Sell Out when she did the big scam, quit her job and bought a house in the country. You just know the cottage industry she is trying to \\"help\\" with her ever-increasing guidance, will blossom into a hugely successful, Kate-run conglomerate.<br />Kate was inept with her household help.  Her cleaning lady has a back problem that does not allow her to bend or reach over her head; therefore, she can only clean (?) what is right in front of her.  And the Nanny Problem.  How can this be?  We Americans know the English invented nannies and train them so the parents only meet their sweet smelling, well-dressed offspring twice a day.  Not so at Kate's house. I wondered why it wasn't in the job description to have Nanny feed, bathe and pajama the children by the time Kate came home. Also, the English are famous for turning over theirtykes to a good boarding school at an ungodly early age and sustaining only a nodding acquaintance with said tykes thereafter.  Not Kate.  I believe she will strain to keep the children with her until they are both gray haired. It's enough to make you lose faith in the English Way of Life.<br />\\"IDKHSDI's\\" Kate is a vast improvement over Bridget Jones.  Kate doesn't meander through her life.  She has depth and a willingness to change.  She is interesting enough to make the pages fly and we, as readers dream up suggestions by the carload to improve her sense of well being.  Remember you can spend as much of Kate's money you want make things better!<BR>-sweetmolly-Amazon Reviewer
B00005JKBC|4.0|In general, \\"Spy Game\\" is a pretty standard Hollywood espionage flick.  The plot is improbable, the dialogue a little overdetermined, many of the characters [typical].  Yet, despite its faults, I find it to be quite a bit better than the average spy flick.  The set-up in itself is interesting: Robert Redford's character becomes something of a spy within the CIA; the line between good guy and bad guy is not so easily drawn here.  The script is merely serviceable, but the film creates an adrenaline-soaked atmosphere through its jumpy camera-work and unexpected ... twists.  Unlike most action movies, it gives you something to think about, a ... situation to consider and question.  Plus, how many big Hollywood flicks have a juicy, sly Charlotte Rampling cameo?  That in itself deserves credit.

B00006LLLN|5.0|It's about time that the award-winning Alison Krauss and Union Station released a live album, and a double-CD doozy it is! A live DVD of the same show is also forthcoming. Recorded in April, 2002 at the Palace Theater in Louisville, KY as part of their \\"New Favorite\\" tour, the album serves up 25 songs that mix newer material with older hits like Let Me Touch You For Awhile, The Lucky One, Everytime You Say Goodbye, Broadway, Faraway Land, When You Say Nothing At All, and Oh Atlanta. One of the songs (Down to the River to Pray) was recorded live at Austin City Limits. This package is a true testament to the tightness of AKUS, and a live album like this clearly exudes musical energy as the band feeds off the enthusiastic response of a large appreciative audience.  While applause can be slightly annoying, once the band launches into a song, there is little in the way of noise distraction and disruption with the exception of some minimal clapping along on \\"Bright Sunny South.\\" The musicians, soundmen and recording engineer were all doing their jobs right and in professional workmanlike style on those two fateful days in Louisville.<br />Besides Alison, the band includes Barry Bales, Ron Block, Jerry Douglas, Dan Tyminski and on about half of the tracks, guest percussionist Larry Atamanuik. The appearance of this tasteful Nashville session drummer serves to reinforce the eclectic nature of this band's repertoire that is probably best classified as acoustic country, with occasional bluegrass selections. And, it is their instrumental virtuosity and vocal prowess that have personalized their sound and built their large fan base. Tyminiski handles the lead vocals on four tracks, and he's probably at his soulful best singing a song like \\"The Boy Who Wouldn't Hoe Corn.\\" Ron Block sings his own composition, \\"Faraway Land.\\" Music arranging has always been a clear strength of this band, and I always especially enjoy hearing how the group capitalizes on Ron Block's versatility as both a guitarist and banjo-player. If only he could play both instruments at once in a live show like this. Four instrumentals are included: Choctaw Hayride, Cluck Old Hen, We Hide and Seek, and Jerry Douglas' solo on A Tribute to Peador O'Donnell/Monkey Let the Hogs Out. The only thing I occasionally miss in AKUS' sound is more mandolin, but Dan Tyminiski does pick that instrument on five tracks. When one audience member shouts \\"I love you, Alison,\\" another chimes in with \\"I love you more.\\" After listening to this project, we'll all surely fall into either the former or latter category of fans. Satisfaction Guaranteed! (Joe Ross, staff writer, Bluegrass Now)both a guitarist and banjo-player. If only he could play both instruments at once in a live show like this. Satisfaction Guaranteed! (Joe Ross, staff writer, Bluegrass Now)

B00006879E|5.0|Maroon 5 brings to us a brilliant mix of soul, rock, funk, and R&B so slickly crafted that most people wont know how to take them.  The intense vocal range of frontman Adam Levine is matched perfectly by this incredibly smooth band.  Dueling guitars, jazzy keys, and a rhythm section cooler than Barry White in the late 70s bring this massive sound to a head.<br />The harmonies brought forth on this disc bear an uncanny resemblance to Michael Jackson, though the utter lack of synth-pop backing, creates a sound all its own.  The album, Songs About Jane, is clearly devoted primarily the relationships and love-life of Levine, who is also the bands main songwriter.  Probably the most outright pop tune on the album would be She Will be Loved, which happens to tell the most interesting story lyrically.  This track is apparently about the singers infatuation and empathy toward an attractive young prostitute, who he visits frequently in an attempt to make her feel as beautiful as she is.<br />It is difficult to pick out standout tracks on an album like this, where every song is so equally fantastic.  The...funk-tastic tune Not Coming Home, along with the slowed down lounge groove, Secret, are 2 of my personal favorites, although every song on here has strength alone.  The first single, which to this point has only received minimal notice and success, Harder to Breathe, is clearly the most alternative of the album.  Sweetest Goodbye is also a great way to wrap this album up and leave the listener smiling from this R&B tinged love song.<br />Overall, this may be one of the best albums of 2002.  The talent for writing great pop tunes that stray from the synth-pop and electronic influences of current radio mainstays may make this album great, but I can imagine the difficulty in marketing a band like this to mainstream audiences who fight tooth and nail to place everything in categories and genres.  If you really want a great band to chill and relax to, but one that never falls into the category of background music then Maroon 5 is for you.  And if youre a woman, age 18-30 and youre single, check out Maroon 5 live, because from listening to Mr. Levines lyrics, I can tell you one thing  this guy LOVES women.<BR>9/10<

B000069HK2|5.0|With as much music as I listen to, I am constantly searching for something new.  While listening to the Atticus compilation, I happened across a band called \\"The Used\\", with their first single, \\"A Box Full of Sharp Objects\\".  My ears perked up as I heard this new style of melodic hardcore.  What is new about it, is the fact that this isn't hardcore music with melodic vocals, but a schizophrenic, constantly mutating mix of beautifully clean melodic rock, and gut wrenching hardcore.  In their first full length, The Used tear through 13 new songs, always varying between sweet melodies and brutal screams.  The album opens up with its only let down, \\"Maybe Memories\\".  This song sounds like it was stolen directly from an older Deftones album.  The second track, \\"The Taste of Ink\\", pushes the album in its true direction.  The vocals and lyrics on this album, no matter how talented the band may be, are what set The Used apart from the rest of this scene.  Vocalist, Bert, has one of the most incredible ranges I have ever heard in this style of music.  The lyrics are so well written and honest, full of agonizing wonder, tragedy and triumph, there is a song for everyone on this album.  As a whole, the album leans more to a pop feel than it does hardcore, but in this case, that does not diminish the artistic impact the album makes.  The album presses forward with its infectious rock, overlain vocals, and screams at the most perfect placements.  The one acoustic song on the album is definitely a stand out.  Instead of leaning toward the usual heartbroken emo sound that will generally be found in an albums \\"sole acoustic song\\", the song touches upon solitude and the bliss of ignorance.  After the album closes out with \\"Pieces Mended\\", which is a great track to tie the rest of the work together, the band sneaks in a brutally hardcore secret song, about 6 minutes after the last track ends.  I can't stress how much I recommend this album.<BR>Rating:  9/10<br />For reviews like thisand much more, visit bigtouchin.com

B00008H2LB|4.0|Lets start out by saying that Linkin Park has been one of my guilty pleasures since One Step Closer had debuted as the bands first radio single.  Thus, when Meteora was released, I made sure to snatch it up early.  Like many fans, I have been waiting to see how their next full length would fare against the grotesque mesh of singles that made up Hybrid Theory.  Overall, it can be simply stated that Meteora, although a more mature step for the band, will probably not win over any new fans.  If you remained one of the haters of the Linkin Park sound, there will be nothing on this disc to change your mind.  <br />The aforementioned maturity in the songwriting comes primarily from the skill in which they blend their various sonic elements.  The samples are slightly more prominent, although matched perfectly by the chunky guitars, the groove of the rhythm section, and the layered vocals.  Every song is layered so thickly with these combinations, which are so skillfully meshed, that the hooks just come naturally.  As a whole, this album is a bit heavier than Hybrid Theory, and also contains a slightly stronger hip-hop vibe.  <br />Standout tracks like Faint, and Nobodys Listening along with the beautifully crafted Breaking the Habit are what really propels this band beyond the shadow of their first full length.  Hit the Floor is a slow but aggressive hip-hop track with lots of screaming at chorus.  The talent that goes into making every single track on an album worthy of the status of a chart topping single is never lost on Meteora.  In fact, out of the 13 tracks, excluding the intro and the Instrumental Session, all 11 actual songs could be singles.<br />The time and thought that went into this release is apparent in every track, and every page of the insert, covered with artistic photography, notations from the band explaining every single song, and the fold out case concealing the multimedia loaded album is reallysomething to revel at.  Even with as mainstream as this band is, and knowing full well that by the end of the year at least 6 of these songs will be on the radio and MTV every 15 minutes, there are so many bands out that who need to take a lesson from Linkin Park in how far you should go in crafting a masterpiece.  <BR>8/10<br />For Reviews like this and much more, visit bigtouchin.com

0786868694|4.0|I  approached this cookbook skeptically.  It can be difficult to separate the cooking from the cult of personality, so to critique the recipes is to critique the woman.  The cookbook has lots of chatter and lots of white space, but Nigella Lawson is a charming woman, so the chatter is friendly and companionable, and the book has lots of white space but it is slender and elegant and filled with beautiful photographs of every dish.  Sections are organized as Breakfast, Comfort Food, TV Dinners, Rainy Day, Trashy, etc.  These are more colorful than helpful, but one can find recipes by name or ingredient in the well-constructed index.  No nutritional information is given for the recipes, but that's just as well.<br />I've tried eight recipes so far (and have many more marked to try).  Of those eight, I would say three were resounding successes: the icing for the chocolate fudge cake will be at the top of my list whenever I need an airy but flavorful frosting; the sweet corn pudding was very good; and the double potato and halloumi bake was delicious though I couldn't find the sheep's milk cheese required for two of the book's recipes, even at a gourmet cheese shop.  Two recipes were servable if not very exciting.  And three of the eight recipes did not work for me at all.  My Mozzarella in Carrozza, for example, never resulted in a stretchy warm concoction that I could pull lustily from my teeth, my neck outstretched in voluptuous splendor, though I tried several times.<br />Three additional comments: Several of the recipes I tried benefited from the addition of spice.  Secondly, recipes have been lazily retooled from the metric units originally used, so instructions often call for multiple multi-measurement ingredients -- 1 cup + 2 T flour, 1/4 cup + 1 t sugar, etc etc.  Finally, quite a few recipes call for self-rising flour; you can make the equivalent of 1 cup of self-rising flour by mixing 1 cup of all-purpose flour + 1-1/2 teaspoons of baking powder  + 1/4 teaspoon of salt.<br />Ultimately this is not a flawless effort, but Nigella has the charm and talent to pull off a successful personality cookbook, and though results might be mixed, the good recipes are archetypal. That ain't bad.n of salt.  <br />Ultimately this is not a flawless effort, but Nigella has the charm and talent to pull off a successful personality cookbook, and though results might be mixed, the good recipes are archetypal. That ain't bad.

B00008DDXC|5.0|This second Harry Potter film is a fine adventure, and this two-disk DVD edition has fun features. Disc One contains the film (you have to purchase widescreen or fullscreen rather than getting both on one disc -- what's up with that?), which can be heard in English or Spanish, or read in English, Spanish or French. The disc also contains a cast and crew listing (which includes neither Moaning Myrtle nor Mr. Weasley!); a theatrical trailer; and an entertaining synopsis trailer of the first film.<br />Disc Two navigates easily and contains a number of good items, including: an enlightening 16-minute conversation with author Rowling and screenwriter Kloves; charming interview snippets from virtually every speaking actor; production sketches; a photo gallery; a 17-minute behind-the-scenes featurette of the production team as they tackle Dumbledore's Office; Lockhart's Classroom, a facsimile replete with certificates, books and pictures all concerning Magical Him; a quiz; an interactive tour of Diagon Alley that lumbers a bit through Navigation Alley but contains clever images; and two games, one getting through the Chamber of Secrets, the other navigating the flying car through the forest -- the latter looks really fabulous. Nineteen additional scenes are available, and they are a lot of fun. I wish several had been used in the theatrical release, including a fine bridge between (a) Hermione's telling Harry he could, indeed, be the heir of Slytherin, and (b) Harry's feeling the curious stares of his housemates; the scene is beautiful -- Harry looking forlornly out over a Lake District-y looking place. I think it's a scene that could easily have been overplayed, but Radcliffe pulled it off nicely.  It convinced me that Radcliffe may grow in the role and benefit from another director.  (I'd love to see Tim Burton tackle an instalment!)  I think all three young leads are better this time around, and of course the entire supporting cast is flawless. Sets and props are inspired, and the effects are breathtaking. Tom Riddle's wordy denouement is less successful on the screen than it was in the book, but therein lies the difference in the mediums.<br />All in all, I'd say this DVD set is lots of fun. The film is very good and the extras are quite entertaining.<br /><br />Caveat: the movie may be too intense for young viewers, people who don't like spiders, or people who don't like snake-ish things.and the effects are breathtaking. 0451207521|5.0|Ok, this was my very first Ken Follett book, and it really just blew me away!! It's one of the best books I have read in a very looong time... <br />Jackdaws consists of an excellent fast moving plot that keeps you rooted to the book from the first page to the last. Follett throws in a couple of plot twists for good measure too. <br />Then there's the matter of the characters themselves, which IMO is the factor that makes or breaks any novel. The characters here were vivid and well fleshed out. Flick Clairet was to me, especially amazing. <br />All the characters were totally unlike the flat undeveloped garbage you get in some books. Here, Follett ensured that they were properly developed into very three-dimensional people. Even the villians had many sides to them. Dieter Franck, the German Officer was one of the best \\"baddies\\" simply because he wasnt completely bad. Follett showed us his human side time and time again till it got to a point where you understood that this man wasnt all evil. You simply could not bring yourself to hate him in the way that other books of this genre might have you detesting the sadistic Nazi officers. He was simply an officer doing his duty the way Flick was doing hers. I actually grew to respect him.<br />An excellent book by anyone's standards. Hopefully we'll see it as a movie one day!
0786867973|5.0|This cookbook has many good recipes, lots of friendly Nigella-chatter, and beautiful photographs of almost every dish. Sections are organized as Cakes, Cookies, Pies (savory and sweet), Desserts, Chocolate, Children, Christmas, Breads and Preserves, and one can also find recipes by name or ingredient in the index. No nutritional information is given.<br />I've tried six recipes so far and have many more earmarked. Of the six I've made, five were quite successful and one was fine but unexciting.  The burnt-butter brown-sugar cupcakes are fabulous; the brownies are perfect examples of the dense, gooey style; the gingerbread with lemon icing and the cranberry upside-down cake were both delicious; and the white bread was a very good big rustic loaf.  The author generously acknowledges her sources in the text and in the bibliography and acknowledgements sections.<br />So far I've thoroughly enjoyed this personality cookbook, really like the recipes I've tried so far, and look forward to trying many more.

B00005JLRT|2.0|Folks, \\"Nemesis\\" is little more than a remake of \\"The Wrath of Khan.\\"  Think about it.  A villain from the past (sort of), a weapon of mass destruction, a climactic space battle, and the death (sort of) of a beloved character while saving the Enterprise.<br />Why does Paramount continue to do these movies on the cheap?  Yes, the special effects are spectacular, but the makers continue to compartmentalize Trek movies.  They do it so they don't have to spend a lot of money on sets.  You have the ship, and then you have the various wastelands/wilderness \\"sets\\".  Don't believe me?  Nemesis:  wasteland dune buggy chase.  The Final Frontier:  wasteland \\"Paradise\\" outpost and El Capitan climb.  The Search for Spock:  wasteland planet destroying itself.  Generations:  desert planet for Soran's launch site.  First Contact:  wilderness missile launch site.  ENOUGH!!!<br />Just about everything else in the movies is aboard ship.  Mind you, I don't object to that, per se, but why can't they spend some money on some futuristic sets and try to make at least one epic Star Trek film???<br />As for the movie, Shinzon is adequate as a villain, but I certainly don't believe he would have it in him to wipe out the entire Romulan Senate.  Sorry, that's just too farfetched.  The wedding and B-4 plot diversions are enjoyable, but that's all they are--minor diversions.  The special effects are fabulous, but they should have thought about developing a story that looks beyond CGI.<br />It's not hard to see why this movie was a box-office disappointment.  It also apparently was a disappointment to a great many fans considering some of the reviews here.  <br />Overall, a poor way to end a legendary series of movies.  They should have made a movie to remember rather than one to forget--this movie was as weak as the first one.

B000002LND|5.0|When you have as many hits as Madonna, you don't need filler. From \\"Holiday\\", which just gets better as time goes by, to \\"Like A Virgin\\" to \\"Vogue\\" this album sums up the first half of a ground-breaking career. <br />I enjoy the chronological order of the singles. When greatest hits packages randomly lay down tracks you miss the 'arc' of the artist's career.  With this album you can listen every step of the way from the Madonna-lite vocals of \\"Borderline\\" to the womanly-growl of \\"Express Yourself\\" and \\"Justify My Love\\".<br />And with \\"Justify My Love\\" Madonna proves that a greatest hits album can produce an outright hit single of its own.  She never stops experimenting- even on a career recap. Although many imitations of this song came out in the 90's, Madonna's breathy song-speak was truly fresh at the time.<br />Although the other new track \\"Rescue Me\\" is not on the level of the other songs on this album, it is interesting to note that this same deep voice was once declared \\"minnie mouse on helium\\". <br />A lot of greatest hits packages seem to disappoint- either they are too casual for the die-hard fans, or contain too many obscure tracks for the casual listener.  The brilliant Madonna puts out an album that is must for any fan of her music, or of pop music in general.

B000002LGQ|5.0|In her 20 years as the driving force behind most of our pop culture, Madonna has tried her hand at just about everything. With 1989's \\"Like A Prayer\\" she truly fused rock, pop, religion, sex and feminist politics.  Rolling Stone was right to call this as close to art as pop music gets. This album is so cohesive it is best when not viewed as a collection of hit singles (although almost half the tracks were) but as a body of inspired work which is so late-80's, so Madonna, and so pop music, she confidently takes the pop music throne. It is her perfect understanding of the essence of the decade, herself, and the platform that made her a world superstar, which makes this album so unique and so special.  While her early contemporaries like Michael Jackson and Prince lost touch with the public, Madonna came back with this album and with it she produced a hit pop album with more depth than courage than any she has done before or since.<br />Onto the songs.<br />\\"Like a Prayer\\": the most perfect pop single ever produced. Only Madonna would contrive a church choir for back up singers. The guitars rock.  This is a pop-radio revival.<br />\\"Express Yourself\\": Female empowerment never sounded so hot.<br />\\"Love Song\\" a duet with Prince. No one would have bought a real love duet between these two.  So they didn't do one. Instead the lyrics brilliantly declare  'this is not a love song!' Strange. Sexy. Should've been a single.<br />\\"Till death do us part\\"  Again, only Madonna would write a dance track about abuse and a failed marriage. How it works is somehow a mystery- yet this might be the best and most profound track on the album. Other artists wish they had the foresight to make this kind of music.<br />\\"Promise to Try\\" Forget your power ballads, all you Celine Dions and Mariah Careys.  This ballad has more poignancy because of its lack of vocal showiness. Madonna's most perfect ballad of her career.<br />\\"Cherish\\"  The best pop single of the album. She throws back to the girl groups of the past and comes up with platinum. Clever lyrics are never deep, but will hook any listener.<br />\\"Dear Jessie\\"  Who says Madonna doesn't have heart? Bizzarre and childlike, this is another side of endlessly fascinating icon.<br />\\"Oh Father\\" Probably the edgiest ballad ever released to mainstream radio, this wasn't a monster hit, but her vocals have never been better and the arrangement is glorious.  Best video of career as well.<br />\\"Keep it Together\\"  the most underrated dance track of any album, if this had been released earlier as a single it surely would have been a gigantic hit. Again, only Madonna can write a four minute dance track that encapsulates the importance of family ties.<br />\\"Spanish Eyes\\"  Madonna has always flirted with the Spanish culture and with this track she goes beyond the earlier ballad 'La Isla Bonita' to produce a song of love, loss and longing.<br />\\"Act of Contrition\\" Not a song really.  A tongue in cheek repentance for everything we just heard.  The perfect punctuation for a pivotal album. Let the 80's end. A new decade is upon us..girl groups of the past and comes up with platinum. B000002J1B|4.0|After masterminding one of the most potent examples of prog-rock excess (1973's Tales From Topographic Oceans), YES pull back the reins and format their follow-up, Relayer, after their classic Close To the Edge disc; one side-long piece (for you vinyl folks) with two 'shorter' tracks on side two. And once again, the format works.<BR>YES proved with this album that it isn't the length of the tracks that made Tales so difficult to swallow; it was the rambling, noodling meandering arrangements. The Gates Of Delirium, clocking in at nearly 22 minutes, showed the band's ability to utilize the space given to say what needed to be said and do so in a way that was exciting, vital, and interesting.<BR>The track starts off as a sort of mid-tempo tune (with vocalist Jon Anderson's lyrics, based on the book War and Peace-- remember, this is prog rock!) and there are moments you could swear Kansas ripped off.<BR>Then the track takes off into more aggressive territory, building into an orgy of musical chaos reminiscent of the wild, weird opening section of Close To the Edge, only here the band sounds tougher, more angular, more quirky, with flashes of King Crimson-type bombastics. <BR>When the listener feels they cannot bear it anymore, the group pulls it all back into focus, and kicks into one of the grooviest moments on a YES disc. Drummer Alan White and bassist Chris Squire lock in and don't let go as guitarist Steve Howe fleetingly jams in his unique style over them. Underpinning the whole thing, and laying out an unassuming palatte of soundscapes is new recruit Patrick Moraz. Moraz proves less flashy than veteran keys-man Rick Wakeman, but no less formidable.<BR>The track then changes direction once again, and dissolves into a gorgeous mini 'song within a song', the so-called \\"Soon\\" section. The simple beauty of the melody and music counterbalances the complexities of what had proceeded it, and takes the listener into a state of sonic bliss. <BR>The remainder of the album continues first with the 'we-can-play-faster-than-you-and-just-to-prove-it-we-will' wackiness of Sound Chaser. One is both struck with awe by the band's quickness -- and also numbed by it. It has to be heard atleast once, which is probably more than the most die-hard fan can handle.<BR>Then the album closes with To Be Over, featuring great pedal steel from Steve Howe. The track has a sort of pensive quality, a lilting gentleness to it that builds to a comfortable climax. A fitting end to an exceptional disc. <BR>If you are not a YES fan, this is not really the place to start; stick with Fragile or 90125. But for die-hards, this is a tough one to beat. Great album.
B00008BXJF|5.0|King Crimson has always made a point of being deliberately different and always on the cutting edge. This album is no exception. Where else can a master guitar player (Fripp) make his instrument also sound like a mellotron, a violin or a synthesizer?<br />The motif of the album is in the four short versions of \\"The Power To Believe\\". The first is meek and sweet with Eastern percussion while the last concludes the session with Fripp's guitar soaring like a solo violin and a whole variety is in between. \\"Level Five\\" displays the tight, almost violently aggressive sound King Crimson has nearly patented. It's a great opener.<br />Of course, there are plenty of great prog-rock songs such as \\"Eyes Wide Open\\", a harken back to \\"Three Of A Perfect Pair\\" and \\"Facts Of Life\\" with cynical lyrics that made fun of the rich and greedy (\\"six millionaires crawling on a plate\\") and immorality (\\"just because you can doesn't mean you should\\").<br />'Newbie boy bands' get skewered on \\"Happy With What You Have To Be Happy With\\", with lyrics like, \\"I'm gonna have to write a chorus, We're gonna need to have another chorus...\\". It's nicely vicious. Not all is parody, as is shown with a great progressive build of a song with an urgent crescendo in \\"Dangerous Curves\\".<br />Adrian Belew is obviously having a good time and is a great compliment to Fripp's guitar work. Trey Gunn is amazing with all his bass instruments and Pat Mastelotto is extremely confident. Mastelotto may not have the flash that Bill Bruford displays, but his competency and pinpoint accuracy more than makes up for it. This 'King Crimson' grouping is just as tight as any and it's great to hear more innovative and fascinating mixes of talent and instruments thirty years on.
B000001ESP|5.0|Yeah, Rush made great music before 1981, and they would continue to do so after, but that year was THE year for Rush, the much-maligned Canadian prog-rock trio. They managed to create an album that was both truly progressive and truly listenable. With Moving Pictures, they hooked the mainstream, and suddenly the band had fans all over the place.<BR>You can thank, firstly, great songs. The quirky musicians, known for their ability to play circles around anyone else in rock and doing so over super-complex arrangements, wrote some interesting, compelling tunes for this album. Tom Sawyer, Limelight, and Red Barchetta were all hits of varying degree and they showcase a cohesive melding of prog-rock leanings with mainstream rock sensibility; they knew when to pull in the reins, and when to cut loose. Tom Sawyer features a memorable synth line (provided by vocalist/bassist Geddy Lee) and mindblowing drumwork (by Neil Peart). Limelight is guitarist Alex Lifeson's showcase. The main riff is great, and so is Lifeson's sublime solo, played with power and finesse.<BR>The instrumental, YYZ, swings like mad, slowing down only once for listener's to catch their breath before slinging right back into the track. Lee's bass playing is phenomenal, but not overwhelming.<BR>Of course, being a prog-rock band, they have an 'epic' piece here, in the form of The Camera Eye. The track is interesting, but ultimately unsatisfying when stacked against the rest of the disc. Witch Hunt (subtitled 'part 3 of FEAR' -- fans would have to wait to figure that out later) is a strong track with a sort of cinematic sweep to its execution. The album closes with Vital Signs, which sounds more like a song by The Police than Rush. The techno-reggae vibe was (at the time) cutting edge and was a hint at things to come from this impressive band.<BR>Secondly, you can thank the production. The sound of this disc is still amazing. It has to be heard on a good sound system to fully appreciate the nuances of each composition. <BR>Rush had come a long way from those sweaty bars in Toronto playing Led-Zeppelin-esque hard rock. With Moving Pictures, Rush had cemented their own place in rock and roll, with their own distinctive style. If you thought Permanent Waves was good, check this out. This one is a keeper.
0385504209|5.0|Okay, this was the first Dan Brown book I've read and it was nothing short of EXCELLENT. The writing is fresh and doesn't waste time wwith lagging descriptions; the observations made of interesting and give you a good scope of the characters and settings.<br />Robert Langdon, a symbology professor at Harvard, finds himself mixed-up in the case of the murder of the famous currator of the Louvre. Accompanied by the victim's clever granddaughter, Sophie Nevue, the two make their escape from Paris, on a mysterious scavenger hunt linked to the Priory of Sion, an ancient organization that protects the Holy Grail from the Vatican Church. Sophie, who had not spoken to her grandfather in a decade because of a Sion rite that she had witnessed, starts to realize the truth about her family.<br />Her grandfather's murderer, an agent of the Opus Dei, a strictly conservative Catholic organization, continues to chase them through Europe, alongside Parisian police.<br />A spicy work; Dan Brown shows enormous prowess at his trade. I loved all the history interwined with the plot and the fascinating conspiracy of Christ's questionable divinity. This the laugh, sit-on-the-edge of your chair, and make-you-think type of book. Top notch adventure and a twist of romance. Perfect.<br />-Liaden
0783231032|4.0|I have to admit; I love 1941.  There's some insane part of me that gets a cheap thrill from watching Hollywood Boulevard being destroyed by a bunch of total morons.  1941 may not be a great movie, but then again, no one was expecting it to be GONE WITH THE WIND.  It's just an insane comedy that I happen to love.<br />The film has several different plots, all of which come crashing together during the last hour and a half of the movie.  The Japanese, parked off the coast of California in a large Japanese submarine, make plans to blow up Hollywood.  They are led by Japanese commander Commander Mitamura (played by Toshiro Mifune) and Nazi Captain Vonkleinschmidt (played by Christopher Lee).  Back on land, Wally (Bobby DiCicco), aided by best friend Dennis (Perry Lang), hopes to win the jitterbug contest with Betty Douglas (Diane Kay), who is chased around by serviceman Chuck \\"Stretch\\" Sitarski (Treat Williams).  Betty's friend Maxine (Wendy Jo Sperber) lusts after Sitarski, and Betty's father Ward (Ned Beatty) recieves an anti-aircraft gun that bears a striking resemblance to an army tank.  Meanwhile, General's aide Loumis Birkhead (Tim Matheson) lusts after Donna Stratton (Nancy Allen), who is turned on by planes.  And bursting through all of this is loud and crude nutcase pilot Wild Bill Kelso (John Belushi) who makes it his business to blow everything up.<br />The first hour or so is far more calm than the last hour and a half.  During this, writers Robert Zemeckis and Bob Gale (who went on to do BACK TO THE FUTURE) set up all the characters and plot lines, not all of which I have mentioned yet.  The gags are slowly milked out to their fullest extent, and Slim Pickens has a funny role as a drunk captured by the Japanese  The last hour and a half, however, is a blast in the face of music, sound and imagry.  There's lots to see here; a ferris wheel rolling off a peir, with two guys (Murray Hamilton, Eddie Deezen and Deezen's wooden dummy) on top of it; Beatty's wife Lorraine Gary watching in horror as he drives a tank through their home; and, of course, Kelso and all the others blowing up half of Hollywood Boulevard while General Stillwell (Robert Stack) watches DUMBO in the local theatre.<br />The music by John Williams is unforgettable, hummable and, as usual, absolutely perfect.  The visual effects are amazing for their time, and even more amazing when you consider the fact that they're better than most of today's computer effects.  All the technichal elements in the film are superb.<br />Will you like this movie?  I don't know.  I did, but then again, my sense of humor isn't exactly sophisticated.  I thought 1941 was crazy fun, but don't see it if you have weak ears, and if you have the volume on high, brace yourself.  The last hour and a half is basically people screaming and stuff blowing up, and it's LOUD.  But I still found 1941 to be, in a goofy way, loud and insane fun.<br />The DVD is great.  There's an excellent 110 minute documentary on the making of the film, and no wonder it's excellent; it was directed by documentary maker extraordinaire Laurent Bozereau.  By the way, the cut on the disc is an extended cut that has about 26 minutes of extra footage.  I don't remember the original version well enough to comment on the difference however.  Also included are excellent production notes, great photo galleries, three fun trailers (the first of which has specially prepared footage), original reviews (which are, for the most part, really, really nasty), and some interesting deleted scenes.  Also, Universal has graciously cut the movie up into 60 (!) different chapters.  Talk about packaging!<br />It may not be a classic, and it may not really be about anything besides stuff getting destroyed, but 1941 is still VERY, VERY FUNNY.  I recommend it both for the movie and this EXCELLENT DVD.

He is in a class of his own. 50 is just a thug rapper, but is a damn good one at that. <br />Recommanded, but don't expect Illmatic, Ready To Die, or The Chronic.

B00006RIO7|5.0|Before I begin, let me say that I loved the movie, Chicago. So if you didn't like the movie, you probably won't like the soundtrack.<br />1. Overture/And All That Jazz<br />The definitive Chicago song. It starts with an awesome instrumental bit and then Catherine Zeta-Jones joins in after a couple of minutes. This is the kind of song that will get in your head and never come out. A very fun track.<br />2. Funny Honey<br />Rene Zellweger's singing; you'll either love it or hate it, and that goes the same with this track. A great song with piano music.<br />3. When You're Good to Mama<br />This song shocked a whole bunch of people, because nobody knew that Queen Latifah could sing. And sing very well, at that. A catchy background instrumental bit complete with fun lyrics make this a great song.<br />4. Cell Block Tango<br />Many people's favorite song, and for good reason. Tons of energy in this one. I haven't met a single person who didn't like it. I even showed it to a kid who didn't want to see Chicago and now he wants to see Chicago!<br />5. All I Care About<br />Richard Gere's first song on the CD. One of my favorites. I love the climax near the end.<br />6. We Both Reached For The Gun<br />A great song. Starring Richard Gere as himself AND Roxie. Very, very fun to listen to.<br />7. Roxie<br />Same as Funny Honey. I love this song as well. Also gets stuck in your head.<br />8. I Can't Do It Alone<br />Mostly instrumental, except for a few &quot;First I..., Then She..., Then We...&quot; I challange you to find a person who doesn't like this one.<br />9. Mister Cellophane<br />If you thought that I was just going to say good things about the CD, then here's the part where I complain. Mister Cellophane isn't very fun to listen to at all. It's not John C. Rielly's fault, his singing it great, it's just that the song's seems to move lazily. I often skip this one.<br />10. Razzle Dazzle<br />One of the best songs on the CD. Richard Gere sings along with a few girls.It gets really energetic at the end, but it helps if you've seen the movie first.<br />11. Class<br />This is my favorite song on the CD. The lyrics are great and understandable. It's sung by Catherine Zeta-Jones and Queen Latifah and couldn't be done better. Definatly worth a listen.<br />12. Nowadays (Roxie)<br />Roxie sings Nowadays, a great song that sticks with you. Starts with a large instrumental background, but then trasistions to a piano background. Very cool.<br />13. Nowadays/Hot Honey Rag<br />Same as the last one, but sung by Rene and Catherine. Halfway through, they switch to just instrumental. I love it, but I would rather just listen to the movie, because the sound effects enhance it a whole bunch.<br />14. I Move On<br />Oscar Nominated and for good reason. The song that played during the credits that many people might have missed.<br />15. After Midnight<br />Instrumenal bit that was played durring the Kitty part in the movie. Very fun to listen to.<br />16. Roxie's Suite<br />Also instrumental. It has a &quot;busy city&quot; feeling and is always energetic.<br />17. Cell Block Tango (He Had It Comin')<br />And now for something completely different... I don't think this song will hold very well with the target audience of the movie. It's this crazy ghetto rap bit that takes a bit from the Cell Block Tango scene from the movie. The best I can say is that it's good a &quot;head bobbin' beat&quot;<br />18. Love is a Crime<br />Same as the last song, not really my cup of tea. The only way it seems to be related to the movie is that the singer randomly shouts &quot;Chicago&quot;. This is a song to boot.<br />Overall, a very awesome CD. I've been listening to it since January.

B000002HAF|5.0|Some say Doolittle - but in my opinion, this is the Pixies best album. This album started the &quot;Steve Albini&quot; craze which was put to good use with Nirvana's &quot;In Utero&quot; and stolen by Weezer on &quot;Pinkerton&quot;, and with good reason, Albini gives this record so much personality, every time I listen to it, it's like talking to an old friend. Joey Santiago's guitar TALKS, and not in a Frampton way. Imagine the Spider-Man villian &quot;Carnage&quot; as a lead guitar. That is Santiago's sound. I sometimes wonder if his guitar is possessed, it sounds as if Santiago has no idea what is going on, I imagine the guitar hovering in the air being played by psychotic, invisible hands. In addition, Lovering's drums are so up and in your face that if you played this on a good stereo, the people in the next room might think you're actually playing drums. Deal's voice is beautiful, her background vocals are excellent. Don't ask what the best songs on this are, they're all classics, but if you must know, my personal favorites are &quot;Where is My Mind?&quot;, &quot;Gigantic&quot; and &quot;Cactus&quot;, but they change daily. This is the best album of one of the greatest and most original bands of all time. As much as I love Nirvana, this leaves &quot;In Utero&quot; and &quot;Nevermind&quot; looking like Raffi. You're only hurting yourself if you don't buy this right now.
